Package civitas.celestis.math

Class Numbers

java.lang.Object
civitas.celestis.math.Numbers
public final class Numbers extends Object
Contains utility methods for numbers.

  • Field Details

    • EPSILON

      public static final double EPSILON
      A small threshold value used in various calculations to substitute a very small interval.
      See Also:
      • Constant Field Values

    • MARGIN_OF_SIGNIFICANCE

      public static final double MARGIN_OF_SIGNIFICANCE
      Any differences below this value will be considered zero. In other words, if two values are different by less than this margin, they will be considered equal by this class.
      See Also:
      • Constant Field Values

  • Constructor Details

    • Numbers

      public Numbers()

  • Method Details

    • requireFinite

      public static double requireFinite(double value)
      Explicitly denotes that a given double must be finite. This is determined by the static method Double.isFinite(double). If the value is finite, this will simply pass through the value to the return value. If not, this will throw an IllegalArgumentException.
      Parameters:
      value - The value to validate
      Returns:
      The value given as the parameter
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - When the given field is non-finite

    • requireRange

      public static double requireRange(double value, double min, double max)
      Explicitly denotes that a given double must be within the range min to max. If the value meets the requirements, this will simply pass through the value to the return value. If not, this will throw an IllegalArgumentException.
      Parameters:
      value - The value to validate
      min - The minimum acceptable value
      max - The maximum acceptable value
      Returns:
      The value given as the parameter
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - When value > max || value < min

    • requireNonNegative

      public static double requireNonNegative(double value)
      Explicitly denotes that a given double must be either zero or positive. Non-finite values are also not allowed.
      Parameters:
      value - The value to validate
      Returns:
      The value given as the parameter
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - When value < 0

    • requirePositive

      public static double requirePositive(double value)
      Explicitly denotes that a given double must have a positive sign. Non-finite values are also not allowed.
      Parameters:
      value - The value to validate
      Returns:
      The value given as the parameter
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - When value < Double.MIN_VALUE

    • requireNonZero

      public static double requireNonZero(double value)
      Explicitly denotes that a given double must not be zero. This only checks for value != 0 and does not filter out non-finite values.
      Parameters:
      value - The value to validate
      Returns:
      The value given as the parameter
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - When value == 0

    • isInRange

      public static boolean isInRange(double value, double min, double max)
      Checks if a scalar is within the specified range.
      Parameters:
      value - The value to check
      min - The minimum acceptable value
      max - The maximum acceptable value
      Returns:
      true if the value obeys the bounds

      Returns:

      Throws:

    • compare

      public static int compare(double v1, double v2)
      Compares two doubles with regard to the MARGIN_OF_SIGNIFICANCE.
      Parameters:
      v1 - The first value to compare
      v2 - The second value to compare
      Returns:
      0 if the values are effectively equal, 1 if the first value is larger, -1 otherwise

    • sum

      @Nonnull public static Vector2 sum(@Nonnull Vector2... values)
      Returns the sum of the provided vectors. This is the equivalent of chaining Vector2.add(Vector2), but is faster due to the lack of re-instantiation every iteration.
      Parameters:
      values - The vectors to sum
      Returns:
      The sum of the provided vectors

    • avg

      @Nonnull public static Vector2 avg(@Nonnull Vector2... values)
      Returns the average of the provided vectors. This is equivalent to the geometric centroid of the vectors.
      Parameters:
      values - The vectors to average
      Returns:
      The average (geometric centroid) of ths provided vectors
